keyTakeAways: A steel cable on the Glória funicular in Lisbon failed to meet safety specifications set by the operator CARRIS.
The cable did not meet the required certification standards for carrying passengers, which is a critical safety failure.
The preliminary investigation by GPIAAF identified serious failures in cable integrity, maintenance practices, and brake functionality.
Maintenance tasks were recorded as completed even when not actually performed, indicating possible negligence or falsification in maintenance records.
The maintenance plan was officially recorded as 'compliant and accepted' by the operator, contradicting evidence of actual compliance.
The incident resulted in at least 16 fatalities and multiple injuries, highlighting the human cost and urgency of safety regulation in public transport.
Eyewitnesses described the derailment as sudden and chaotic, with one man naming himself Bruno, adding a personal dimension to the trauma of the event.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In a deadly September 2025 funicular crash in Lisbon, Portugal, a steel cable on the Glória funicular failed to meet certification and operational specifications set by its operator, CARRIS. The cable snapped shortly after the vehicles began their journey along Calçada da Glória, causing one car to derail and crash into a building, killing at least 16 people and injuring others. Preliminary findings from the Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) reveal serious flaws in cable integrity, maintenance practices, and brake systems, including falsified records that marked maintenance as completed even when not performed. The operator’s maintenance plan was falsely recorded as compliant, raising concerns about oversight and accountability. Eyewitnesses described the event as chaotic and deadly, with one man named Bruno recounting the scene. A final, conclusive report is expected to be released next year.
title: Cable in deadly Portugal funicular crash failed to meet specifications, preliminary report finds
